timeline.bodyText: You seem to have deleted a line you shouldn't.
timeline.author: Prof-Bloodstone

replies.bodyText:
I just double checked and I definitely did not even touch, let alone delete this line. AFAIK the first sign is the git diff, the second sign (that is missing in the change) would be the patch diff. So lines in patch-commits that only have the first sign should be irrelevant, as they only modified which lines are included in the context of the file in the patch. This probably happened automatically as I only did the following:
./paper patch
./paper edit server
<performed the one-line edit>
./paper edit continue
<commited the change>
replies.author: Scrayos

timeline.author: Prof-Bloodstone

replies.bodyText: I only modified the one line. I guess that the other "changed" lines are caused by the usual heuristics that git performs in order to calculate diffs. It changed which brace it used/where it injects the patch content into the file. But I did not change any line except for the return.
replies.author: Scrayos
